text: Draft at taproom. Pours golden with an inch of white head. Leaves some lacing in the glass. A whisper of malt on the nose. Dry and tight on the tongue with a hint of caramel. Finished clean. Solid.

Half-Liter glass stein on tap at the 2016 Urban Chestnut Oktoberfest. It poured a mostly clear golden colour, very lively foam, long-lasting with lace. Grainy, biscuity, grassy, black pepper spice, noble hop balance. Definitely Germanic in style, with a faint tartness not found in classic examples, but supported the dry finish in a nice way. Tasty and refreshing.Earlier Rating: 12/29/2012 Total Score: 3.6Tasted from bottle into a snifter. It poured a mostly clear orangish-amber color with persistent creamy off-white foam and a little lace. Aromas and flavors of bread, sweet malts, caramel, faint noble hops, faint black pepper. Smooth and balanced, it tasted a bit like an Oktoberfest but fruitier with a mellow spiciness. Mild, balanced and unassuming. Good stuff.

On tap at the brewery. Pours hazy coppery color with a small head. Aroma of some malt sweetness, grain and citrus in the background. Taste of malt sweetness, trace of fruit and grain. Nice bitterness and a clean finish. Moderate body, crisp and flavorful. Enjoyable beer that goes down easy.
Orange clear pour from draft at perennial. White head. Off fruit taste. Basement. Good for the style.
Bottle. Pours a cloudy orange with thick off white head that lasts. The aroma is bready malt, yeast, and caramel. Thin mouth, sweet malt, caramel, light spice, bitter finish, good.

From notes. Tasted on 4/23/13 from a capped 750mL bottle. Pours hazy orange with a thick off-white head that leaves average lace. The nose is bready malt with some spicy, green hops underlying, and just a touch of yeast aroma. The flavor is bread up front, some spicy, bitter, green hops, and the yeast from the nose showing a bit nutty. The body is medium with average, stinging carbonation, and a medium spicy hops and lightly nutty finish.
Tap at Perennial. Very slightly hazy light orange pour with a smaller white soapy head. Sweet caramel malts. Bready. Easy drinker. Very good for the style.

Pour on tap at the brewery, hazy orange pour with white head, aroma brought notes of bread, biscuit, some soapy notes, nice malty, caramel notes, some grass and spice. Taste is a mix of grass, bread, nice sweet vanilla, honey, some yeast, finishing bitter, slightly sweet. Nice.
rich malty aroma. very full body. fantastic malt flavor, they really nailed the festbier/münchener lager flavors. not overly hoppy, a very solid amber lager.
750 ml. bottle purchased at the brewery in March. Pours a clear medium gold with a nice white head. Aroma of malt and grain. Taste is malt, wheat, caramel, spice, and a bit of hops. Very nice brew.

Pint from a bottle at Perennial.  A darker honey gold pour with a kind of funky head.  Light lacing remained.  This beer was grainy, malty, and nicely hopped.  Fruit was nice and it had a moderate bitterness.  Some toastiness and a bit of caramel.  Nice beer.
Bottle picked up at Perennial. Pours a copper color with white head. Grainy, earthy, bready aromas. Toast, grain flavors with a touch of bitterness at the end. Pretty nice lager.
(bottle at brewpub) amber with off white head. Malt aroma. Flavor is sweetish caramel malt, a hint of grassy hops in the finish.
Very cloudy brown.  Thin head.  Very sweet and light.  Like a wheat soda.  Very drinkable.

Sampled at Augusta Bottoms Beer Fest - Pours clear copper / orange with an off-white head.  The aroma has smooth caramel lager maltiness, good amount of toast, light spice and smooth hazelnut.  Medium smooth body with a minor amount of carbonation.  The flavor start with slick lager malt, dry caramel, spice, toffee and a nice balance to everything.  The finish adds some crusty bread.  Really nicely done.

Bottle. From perennial. Tropical fruity but based on caramel malt. Glowing red amber with beige head. Good lacing. Balanced. With malt slightly winning overt in the taste expression, with a nutty biscuity ness. This has a slick drink ability and hop expression that is unique to the style.

Pours a clear pale amber with a nice white head.  Slight bready aroma.  Sweet toasted malt, buttery, bready and light hop taste.  A really good Munich/Marzen!  BTW, this beer is identified as a Munich style lager by the brewmaster.  There is nothing Dort or Helles about it.  Dont know who entered that into the description here, but it goes against the brewers description and the taste, overall appearance and mouth feel.

It poured a golden color with a small white head. The aroma was some  maltiness with hops and a little roastiness. The taste was also similar with maltiness and hops. It was a lighter beer than they normally brew, but still very good.

Draft at brewpub. Pour is clear amberwith a medium white head. Aroma is light biscuit malt with faint hints of floral hops and a touch of roast. Pretty light. Flavor is also quite light with hints of biscuit malt and light floral hops. Very light all around. Session.

Draft at Perennial. Pours a bit darker than a typical Dortmunder/helles; rather than a clear gold, this one is more of an orange color with a small off-white head. Notes of pale and cereal malts, grassy hops, straw, crackers, and toasted sugar. Light-bodied, with medium-high carbonation and a crisp, dry mouthfeel. I split a small one with my wife, so I need to try this one again and re-rate when I get a better handle on it.
